You’re probably fine, but please get that thing checked. Much of the book is about the lives of people working in hospitals, especially surgeons. They are so dedicated to their profession that it often looks as if they are imprisoned by it. It begins in Ethiopia during the 1950s to 1970s, a country full of possibilities and chaos, but then moves to different places, following the doctors who chase the odd beauty of working to heal others. The book takes a hard look at fatherhood and brotherhood, dissecting facets of masculinity. A recurring theme is the human need to find meaning by making something beautiful. The problems I had were that the plot relied on too many coincidences to be credible, felt overly ambitious and unnecessarily long. But, I enjoyed it. I often forgot that I was reading. In Verghese’s words, I inhabited the story. It drew me in, broke me, and put me back together, with no loose ends. review: People say that de Beauvoir wrote this novel as an act of revenge upon the woman who came between her and Sartre. I think it’s more than that. I see iPeople say that de Beauvoir wrote this novel as an act of revenge upon the woman who came between her and Sartre. I think it’s more than that. I see it as a story about de Beauvoir's journey to asserting herself freely: the point where she acted “as alone as in death”. She tells the world that she chose herself, consequences be dammed, because she could only know her reality (this btw is solipsism - de Beauvoir wrote a philosophical novel on the subject of a failed romantic trio and I think that’s very cool). Okay. So, before *she* came to stay, Françoise and Pierre (based on Simone & Jean-Paul) were simply one. They thought of each other not as an “I” or a “you”, but, lovingly (and toxically) as a “we”. They belonged to each other and the world belonged to them. And by “the world” I mean the attractive actors who worked for them and who they wanted to possess. Françoise & Pierre were one and they were free. Françoise freely decided that there was no room in her life for another lover. review: I think that what Bataille is saying in the three stories included in this volume is that eroticism will always destroy the innocents. Unlike de Sade,I think that what Bataille is saying in the three stories included in this volume is that eroticism will always destroy the innocents. Unlike de Sade, whose language is jarringly crude, Batalille writes poetically about violent sex. He is less interested in obscene technicalities, and more in the soul-destroying and body-decaying effects of sex as a response to loss and grief. Bataille philosophy is filthy and dark. And he may have taken pleasure from making his readers unhappy. Each central character lost someone or something important to them. In the first story, My Mother, seventeen year old Pierre lost his father and his piety. He was the submissive son of a woman who became revolting to him. He continued to venerate her like a saint, while painfully realizing that he had no basis for that veneration. His mother’s debauchery nauseated him and his continued respect for her made him – but never her – the object of his own horror. He entered a delirium where he felt lost, and in that lifeless void, he glimpsed God. He decided to follow through the interwoven joy and terror that strangled him from within. The sole remedy for his suffering was to heighten it. After all, doesn’t everyone enjoy walking on the edge of a cliff? Along with revolt, Pierre was gripped by greediness for terrifying pleasures. The more his pleasures strangled him, the more they overpowered him. Happiness hurt him like poison, because, as his mother explained, “pleasure only starts once the worm has got into the fruit, to become delightful happiness must be tainted with poison. All the rest is childishness.” More than love for his mother, Pierre loved the possibility of loving her to the point of no return. They form communities, friendships, and families and try to make it in a society that views them as “other”. They open up, become vulnerable, argue, start feeling like the “other” in small or big ways, and inevitably fallouts happen. The problem isn’t that sometimes people do not fit well into each other’s lives. The problem is that when people form a community some of them can abuse their position of power and privilege and make others feel unsafe and unwanted. Some are gatekeepers to their communities and have the power to invite people in, keep people out, put pressure on some members to become less visible, push members out, and advance some narratives, while silencing others. Communities, friendships and families are complicated, togetherness comes at a cost and fallouts are never simple. But Evaristo nudges the reader towards empathy. Father Urrutia was a literary critic wishing to be acknowledged by a group of highbrow scholars, a mediocre poet in love with the idea of culture, and an amateur politician who lacked a political ideology. He kept silent while scenes of torture took place in dire basements (“one must be very careful with one’s silences. I am responsible in every way”). He was accompanied by fear and hate (Mr. Raef and Mr. Etah – isn’t that clever!). He went whichever way he judged to be more profitable for him. He mingled with wealthy aristocrats and beautiful women who loved art and literature. During times of great social turmoil his main concern was how to preserve church buildings from pigeon shit. For a while, Urrutia was at peace with himself. His conscience was quiet, the horrors he saw were dulled by routine. “And then the storm of shit begins”. Stevens wrote that appreciation for At Night All Blood Is Black will depend on whether you agree with the Shakespearean idea that in a mad world, the madman is best equipped to diagnose our deepest illnesses. David Diop takes two absurd illnesses of our times - war and racism – and tells the tale of a Senegalese soldier’s descent into madness while fighting for the French during World War I.Deciding who exactly is the enemy for this soldier is complicated. The Germans clearly are, but then so are the French and more generally all colonizers. Alfa Ndiaye is also an enemy of himself, hating his humanity, his inner voice of duty, and his innocent sense of morality. When reality has lost all sense of reason, he embraces brutality, revenge, twisted justifications, and an absurd sense of devotion to a more-than-brother who took too long to die. He understands that on the battlefield everyone needs to embrace madness in order to survive. Some become madmen of rage, others become madmen of pain, others madmen of fury. But it is expected that these are all temporary states of madness that are striped off after the fighting ends. Continuous madmen are not tolerated: “madness, after the captain blows the whistle to retreat, is taboo.” Up to a point, brutality and rage are the things that make up a war hero, but after that point is passed the soldier becomes a bloodthirsty savage, a madman, someone to avoid and lock away.At Night All Blood is Black is the confession, and also the testimony, of an experience of war, where race and colonialism are added to the mix. Alfa Ndiaye, tells us in his own unreliable voice, how he turned into a madman with an obsessive sense of purpose. Once he abandoned norms of civility all that is left is a heart wrenching howl of innocence destroyed. Some readers may find this novel hard to digest. You get no moral clarity, no heroes and no villains. Instead you get ambiguity, stories hidden beneath other stories, and plenty of inscrutable violence. His desA man fantasizes about being with a cruel woman. In his vision of a perfect sexual dynamic, he is the slave of a selfish and attractive woman. His desires find release in her need to be the absolute focus of admiring attention. His yearning to please her grows as her intense sensitivity to slights exacerbates. His love for her turns to obsession when her natural impulses drive her to focus on her needs, while ignoring his. She constructs dominance hierarchies based on beauty, athleticism, intelligence, wealth, and social status–all things where he is lacking. She admires people above her and devalues those below her. She is a narcissist par excellence and his most intoxicating fantasy is to completely submit to her will. She uses him for her pleasure and when she inevitably grows bored she discards him like a piece of garbage. Pain and humiliation are the cost of his pleasure. He wants to be disposable, and it hurts like hell to be treated as disposable. In that unique head space where his biggest desires intersect with his biggest fears is where he finds bliss. After all, what else do you expect from a sexual and emotional masochist?As far as fantasies go, Masoch’s masochistic tale, although pioneering in its revelations in late 1800s, is, by my standards, pretty mild. My guess is that Venus in Furs will not scandalize, but rather bore, readers who know a little bit about literary explorations of sexual fantasies.My problem with this work is not about its perversions; it’s about its philosophy. Masoch, unfortunately, uses (mild) kink and BDSM dynamics to draw sweeping conclusions about human nature. In his view – possibly arrived at during various stages of frustrated submissive heterosexual arousal - women (yes, all of them) fall in love with selfish men who dominate them physically and emotionally. So, what about those nice guys™, who, if given the change, would treat women (all of them, for sure) as goddesses? When I approach it from an angle of open curiosity, I see a thought-provoking analysis about the limits of morality, consent, kinky desires and the contextual relevance for the criteria we use to evaluate harmful sexual behaviours. Baker is an attentive writer. He identifies shades of desire, consent, harm and beauty. He can write filth that somehow feels artsy.This book is written as an autobiography. The protagonist, Arno, is a good-natured, sensitive and morally confused voyeur with the power to pause time. Although he could put his gift to useful intellectual uses, he settles for undressing women. He tries to convince his readers that his actions are ethical, because he is not harming anyone when he admires naked women who are frozen in time and will have no recollection of his actions. The typical rules of morality do not apply in a different time dimension, he says. Arno admits that he is dishonest and exploitative, but because he is careful not to physically or emotionally harm anyone, he thinks he’s a decent guy.A layer of complexity is given by the way Arno looks at women. By the act of gazing during paused time he plays out the gendered power difference that reflects the patriarchy. He is the gazer, aware, and in full capacity and the women being gazed upon are helpless objects, unaware and frozen in time. The sexual and aesthetic pleasure he gets is the very definition of the male gaze. The women are completely passive and for a limited time Arno is an active viewer with absolute power. Only Arno’s gaze does not fit into a stereotypical misogynistic box. He is an equal opportunity voyeur, loving the bodies of women of all ages and shapes. Arno does not stop with undressing a body; he imagines detailed female stories and experiences in a surprisingly tender way.Even if all of his tolerant voyeuristic perversions flourish and expire in a timeless space, he hasn’t convinced me that he’s not a sexual predator. She paints detailed melancholic pictures with words about places, objects, and creatures that the world will never see again. She uses the notion that everything comes to an end to comment on a broad range of topics including the silencing of lesbian love poems and letters from most of history, Schalansky’s childhood in East Germany, Armand Schulthess’s obsessive plans to lure women into his home where he staked multiple handmade books about sexuality, and the fictionalized inner speech of an aging Greta Garbo worried about the loss of her Hollywood fame.In a way this is a book that creates space for mourning the things that are missing. In his nonfiction novel “Are the limits of our understanding of mathematical and physical sciences also the limits to our understanding of the world? In his nonfiction novel “When We Cease to Understand the World” Benjamín Labatut takes us on a short, intense and uneven journey into the dark side of science.Scientists like de Broglie, Einstein, Göring, Grothendieck, Haber, Heisenberg, Mochizuki, Scheele, Schrödinger, Schwarzschild, Turing and others made discoveries that bettered human existence. But they also led the way to horrendous suffering.For example, Haber’s discovery of how to extract nitrogen from the air saved the word from famine. He was also part of the team who created Zyklon B, a cyanide-based pesticide that was used to kill millions of Jews.Schwarzschild provided mathematical evidence for the existence of black holes. He also calculated the most efficient trajectories for the poison gas used by the German army during World War I.The search for the Theory of Everything and the scientific struggles between Schrödinger and Heisenberg led to the birth of quantum mechanics, which gave us the internet, our smartphones and also the nuclear bomb.The strokes of discovery are often inexorably tied to insanity, obsession and isolation. The lives of extraordinary people are rarely simple. One of Labatut’s themes is how scientific discovery happens. He envisions thought processes and circumstances that lead to epiphanies, using available historical information and filling the gaps with his own imagination.Fluctuating between fiction and non-fiction, Labatut achieves a book that resembles a dystopian novel. Part historical, part eerie mystery this book is a disturbing and gripping story about the scientists who expanded the boundaries of our world. review: In The Body Keeps the Score, Bessel van der Kolk explores the ways in which our bodies and brains are impacted by traumatic events such as childhood nIn The Body Keeps the Score, Bessel van der Kolk explores the ways in which our bodies and brains are impacted by traumatic events such as childhood neglect, abuse, dysfunctional relationships, violence, accidents, natural disasters or war. Packed with neuroscience, peer-ed research, case studies and gut-wrenching stories of surviving trauma the book explains how trauma floods the body with stress hormones which lead to harmful physiological changes in people’s bodies and brains. Prolonged stress impacts mental and physical health, affecting relationships, employment, education, and enjoyment of life. Trauma primes people to be on constant high-alert, their bodies prepared for a fight or flight response. The parts of the brain that evolved to spot danger remain activated and any small sign of possible danger triggers an acute stress response and overwhelming emotions and physical sensations. These post-traumatic responses make in nearly impossible for survivors of trauma to meaningfully connect with others. Yet, healing from trauma means learning to re-connect with people. The author argues that any trauma treatment needs to help people integrate their traumatic experiences within their overall life memories. In short, with the help of therapy, a traumatic event is slowly transformed from an experience that is constantly relived in the present into a bad memory that no longer makes the body go into a fight or flight response. The book is written in a fairly accessible style, with some technical sections and a lot of human stories. It is an emotionally intense read and a treasure of helpful and science-based information. I thought that some of the treatment suggestions were a bit silly (for example pretending that the couch is one of your main caregivers, and the flower vase another main caregiver, and move them around the room to project your inner world into a three dimensional space), but they are backed by research and do work with some people. If the subject of trauma is of interest, I highly recommend you give this book a try....more

The backdrop is Sofia, with its quirky cafés, beautiful parks, claustrophobic streets and filthy crumbling gray buildings. The language of the prose reminds me of journal entries, which the narrator, an American teacher and gay man, uses to write down his private thoughts in a detailed, but unfinished manner, with long paragraphs - at times longer than one page - and hypnotic language building up to a near climax only to retreat and repeat the process. Each chapter feels like the intimate confession of a nameless man about anonymous characters who had a lasting impact on him. But the style of writing also keeps the reader at arm’s length. The narrator invites you in his most intimate spaces, only to push you away - mirroring the tensions between his sexual fantasy of dominance and submission as BDSM play and the true powerlessness he desired. The writing about sex is explicit, precise, graphic, artistic and sensual, mapping both the physicality of the act and the complicated needs of the characters. The descriptions of the loss of love are graceful and raw, painful and tender, and the atmosphere of disquiet in modern day Sofia reveal what it means to seek connections with the place we inhabit and with those around us. The nine stories are free-standing. Together they make up a non-chronological but tightly symmetric novel, where eight stories reflect each other in thematic opposites about teacher-student mentorship, sadomasochistic sexual encounters, hopes and disappointments about Bulgarian politics, and the power and vulnerability of falling in and out of love. review: Elena Ferrante’s the Neapolitan Novels are a four part series that chronicle the lives and inner conflicts of two highly intelligent women, Elena and Elena Ferrante’s the Neapolitan Novels are a four part series that chronicle the lives and inner conflicts of two highly intelligent women, Elena and Lila, who find that no matter where they live, the jobs they have or the men they love, they can never truly escape the violence and misogyny of their past. The tetralogy, which reads like a single story spanning over five decades, is narrated by Elena, who is - as all the women in Ferrante’s books are - shaped by her surroundings, especially by the violent patriarchal culture which she both interiorizes and resists. By describing her own life, Elena also documents the history of the late 20th century Italy: class divisions, violence, mafia power, accumulated wealth as the ultimate marker of emancipation, conflicts between communists and fascists, protests and rallies, the good intentions of the left-wing educated upper class and the dire reality of the working class struggling to survive. Ferrante does not shy away from delving into the most intimate thoughts and feelings of her protagonists. She describes their conflicting desires, shame, ambitions, resentment, jealousy, envy, intellectual competition, self-destruction, revenge, and self-doubt in such a passionate and visceral way that you feel immersed inside the thoughts of the brilliant women she writes about. Elena and Lila feel the tensions between being daughters and having daughters, being wives and staying independent, being inseparable best friends, and pulling away to define themselves as distinct and original. I have enjoyed these books tremendously. The story is compelling and the writing is beautiful: a mix between mater-of-fact descriptions and thought provoking metaphors and symbols. In the 1950s America, light skinned twins Stella and Desiree disapThe Vanishing Half by Brit Bennett is a story about the dilemmas of racial passing. In the 1950s America, light skinned twins Stella and Desiree disappeared from Mallard, a fictional town where light skin became norm, value and measure of perfection. The town was more of an idea than a place, and that idea became too constricting for the twins’ hopes and dreams. They set out in search of a better life. Stella, abandoned her sister and disappeared once again to become white. Desiree married the darkest man she could find and, after leaving him, returned to Mallard. The novel explores the notions of reinvention, erasure, and the performances of race and gender. For example, Therese, after being bullied by their family and community, became Reese. He tried to save money for his top surgery. On weekends, Barry became Bianca. Jude, the dark skinned bookish daughter of Desiree, failing to lighten her skin, reinvented herself in intellectual ways. Kennedy, the golden-haired self-absorbed daughter of Stella constantly ran away from herself, hiding behind her performances as an aspiring actress. The book is narrated with compassion and has great insights about the roles people play throughout their lives. Bennett doesn’t delve into the psychology of the characters and sometimes it feels as if they are reduced to the performances they played: the reserved twin, the vivacious twin, the loyal boyfriend, the abandoned mother, the egocentric daughter, and the introverted bookish daughter - to name just a few. Also, some of the coincidences in the book seemed a little bit stretched. Overall, I really liked this book. review: JG Ballard said that novelists should be like scientists dissecting a cadaver. His novel Crash is a stylized and clinical dissection of cars and humanJG Ballard said that novelists should be like scientists dissecting a cadaver. His novel Crash is a stylized and clinical dissection of cars and human bodies into units of pain and desire. Ballard’s world “flowers into wounds”, and vehicles are systems of eroticism, waiting to inflict punishment on human bodies. The horror of death and the love of spectacle are inextricably linked into an unholy union. Car crash victims sit in damaged cars like deities occupying a shrine. The language is calm and ruthless, describing blood, contorted bodies, semen, vehicle design and highways. It’s reads like a porn novel about technology. It’s repetitive, flat and it lacks human depth. Sequences of cars crashing are arousing to the fetishists who inhabit Ballard’s denatured landscapes. Each collision sets off a shudder of excitement: “in the complex variations of crushed radiator grilles, in the grotesque overhang of an instrument panel forced into to a driver’s crotch as if in some calibrated act of machine fellatio.” The novel looks at modern life: speed, drama, aggression, advertising, engineering, mass production, paradises of electric highways and the “shared experience of moving together through an elaborately signaled landscape.” People possessing a natural curiosity for the perverse follow car crashes with their cameras and zooming lens, observing and recording every detail of auto-deaths. Some of them go further and begin to fantasize and visualize the deaths and injuries they fear most – those involving their lovers or themselves. Reading this novel is like watching short unrelated clips of crushed machines, dead people, stalker-sadists with cameras and thousands of drivers with their auto lights blazing. It is written with the purpose to unsettle and disturb. Once you are inside the story, there is no place to hide. Ballard will provoke you by saying that car crashes are really a union of sex, human bodies and technology, and if you truly feared crashes you would be unable to ever drive a car. But then, Roth is an author who’s built an entire career by exasperating readers. When I think of Sabbath, I think of a raging 64 year old former puppeteer who seduces twenty year old women, alienates everyone who’s ever loved him, snickers at any form of respectability, sniffs the stolen panties of teenage girls, and either masturbates or urinates on his late mistress’ grave. To compensate, Roth gave him generous amounts of sexual perversions and a propensity for speaking in delightful literary sentences. If wickedness was all there was to Sabbath, this book wouldn’t be the masterpiece that it is. Assuming that one of the aims of literature is to teach empathy, with Sabbath your capacity for understanding will be greatly tested. The moment you start to admire something about him, he’ll spit in your face. He’ll do something so awful and deliberately shocking that your tolerance for him will be pushed to its limits. When you are ready to give up on him, he will surprise you with his humanity and tenderness. Sabbath is fragile, isolated, lonely and in near constant physical pain. review: The book takes the idea of human value and asks what the defining feature of humanity is. What does it take to be treated as fully human? Some of the The book takes the idea of human value and asks what the defining feature of humanity is. What does it take to be treated as fully human? Some of the answers include: originality, social function, the ability to form meaningful connections and falling in love. Much of the plot questions the extent to which originality sits at the heart of being a human. Of course an extreme preoccupation with originality completely ignores the fact that all of us are mix of what we inherited and what we acquired. Taken apart, human desires, questions, ideas, preferences, needs, decisions, and even art, are not as original as we would like to pretend. But taken as a whole, everyone is unique. When you have a society that values originality, narratives about copies, un-originals, and imitators become a powerful strategy to portray people as “less than” and justify using them for the benefit of the originals. The idea of a “copy” pushes on our anxieties and discomfort when our individuality feels threatened. Calling someone a “copy” creates an emotional distance that allows for their oppression and ultimately their instrumentalization. A copy is only valuable in terms of the function it provides for the original. Ishiguro writes critically against this idea of originality. In his book, the human copies – the word “clone” is never used - have unique personalities. They are completely human even if they were modeled after an “original”, and raised as organ donors. On an interesting side note, as another reader of the book pointed out, Ishiguro, in an interview, even extended the idea of originality to translations. When you don’t stop to question it, you’d assume that a translation is not an original text. It’s a copy in another language, right? Ishiguro disagrees. For him a translation is basically a conversation with the original text, not a copy of it, and a good translation, he says, is as valuable as the primary text. In Never Let Me Go, the attempts to portray copied people as less than human are unsuccessful, because people’s uniqueness has a way of squeezing out of the limits the originals impose on them. But that does not save them, since their social value is tied to them being spare parts that they “donate” to save the lives of the originals who occupy a privileged position. In Ishiguro’s dystopian society the donors’ value is their biology and their ability to be good carers for other donors before becoming donors themselves. Art has a special place in the book. Creativity is one way to measure someone’s humanity, because if someone can produce something: a poem, a drawing or a painting, that act of creation gives evidence that there is something deeper inside them. However, at the end, art and creativity did not change the oppressive system. Their only role was to give a voice to people who were on a journey of self-discovery which, heartbreakingly, led to nowhere. Never Let Me Go mirrors the common human experience, but in a magnified way. The characters have short lives, most of them “complete” – a euphemism for dying - before middle age. So, they live briefly under the shadow of death. As they are always outside the nuclear family, their only way to forge connections is to claim community. When they were engaged in relationships they discovered the most about themselves, their desires, needs, fears and anxieties. It was relationships that helped them escape isolation. I thought it was a brilliant move to have one of the copied humans as narrator, because from the start there is a relationship between the story teller and the reader, and that relationship confers agency and freedom to a narrator that is otherwise kept silent in a society that wants to ignore her uniqueness, and only value her for her organs. The role of love is different here than in other sci-fi novels. In dystopias such as Nineteen Eighty-Four or Brave New World, love at least has the potential to become a subversive force that destabilizes an oppressive system. In Never Let Me Go love fails to change anything. Love does not mobilize. Love is like a drug that dulls the senses – like a narcotic, a literature critic wrote – that functions to help donors accept their fate with dignified passivity. And I’m still thinking about that. The plot and the book’s title stand as examples that despite the fact that the characters wanted to be truly seen, none of them were completely understood by the others. Each of them was stuck in their own interpretative repertoire. Each interpreted the experiences of others through a glass darkly. They desired to be understood, and yet, the book suggests that they never were – a conclusion that rings sad but true. I give it a 4/5 rating (the characters’ passivity wasn’t entirely credible to me, but maybe that’s just my bias speaking here). ...more

review: In Madness & Civilization, Foucault looks in detail at the historical meanings of madness and how mentally ill people were treated from early RenaissaIn Madness & Civilization, Foucault looks in detail at the historical meanings of madness and how mentally ill people were treated from early Renaissance until the nineteenth century.Foucault seems to be an incredibly thorough scholar. His wide variety of sources and the amount of historical minutiae are commendable. The problem is that I’m not sure how reliable his work is. For instance, Hieronymus Bosch’s painting, “Ship of Fools”, left an impression on Foucault, who wrote about a medieval tradition of putting the mad on ships and sending them away across the seas and canals of Europe. He described the great entertainment sane people had when the foreign lunatics docked at their harbors. As fascinating as that sounds, it didn’t happen. The painting is symbolic and the ship was inspired by an allegory written either by Sebastian Brant in 1493 or Guillaume de Deguileville in 1486. Given Foucault fertile imagination, his work needs to be read with a grain of salt. Nonetheless, it’s interesting to learn about how the concept of madness changed throughout history, from the inability to cope with horrors, to a consequence of immorality, weakness of character, excess of passion, and the result of an overactive imagination. Classical medical theories assumed that women were especially prone to madness. Women who read too much fiction were at the highest risk, followed by those who liked to sleep late in the morning, and finally, those who dreamed of freedom. With those criteria, it’s no surprise that so many women were considered mad.The ways madness was treated also changed. Mad people were ignored, exposed for entertainment, put to forced labor, locked away in chains and cages, and finally placed into asylums under the supervision of psychiatric doctors. Foucault stressed that none of those solutions worked. I think he wanted to convince readers of Madness & Civilization to become suspicious and critical of social institutions. He used complex language to make too many incomprehensible points - a four volumes worth of them. He often didn’t bother to define his terms and he complicated his arguments unnecessarily. As a reader you’re left in confusion and you need to overuse your imagination to understand what he wanted to say. And he did this A LOT. However, ambiguous prose and badly expressed arguments have one huge advantage: they are super hard to argue against. Who knows, maybe Foucault wanted to protect his work from criticism by making it impenetrable. At times, his abstruse writing is so bad that it becomes meaningless. According to Open Culture, Foucault told his friend John Searle that he complicated his writings on purpose and turned some of it into, and I quote, “incomprehensible nonsense” so that he would be taken seriously by French philosophers. And it’s not a matter of jargon - because with jargon if you’re familiar with the field of science you get it. review: Long before Aggrawal published his book on unusual sexual practices with 547 paraphilias listed in Appendix 1, Marquis de Sade ambitiously outlined hiLong before Aggrawal published his book on unusual sexual practices with 547 paraphilias listed in Appendix 1, Marquis de Sade ambitiously outlined his own list of 600 “passions”. In 1785 he began drafting the hefty plot of The 120 Days of Sodom and blended the fetishes into the main narrative. De Sade wrote in secrecy while imprisoned in the Bastille, and today we only have a draft of his novel. The first chapter is nearly finished and the other three are briefly sketched. But, the material is enough to form an opinion.De Sade tried to do several things. He wrote about the dark side of humans and the natural consequences of absolute power. The book is an example of what a human mind can imagine, and how far a writer can take stories of violence. Four libertines - a duke, a bishop, a judge and a financier - abduct a group of young people and torture them to death in a remote castle. He gave absolute power to royalty, religion, the law and the economy over vulnerable people (mostly children), and set the stage for extreme level of abuse. De Sade introduced into the plot four older women to act as story tellers of unusual sexual experiences. He turned his libertines into an active audience, re-enacting the stories they heard. Maybe Sade hoped to tempt readers into imagining what it would be like to participate in similar activities. But, De Sade did not have Nabokov’s genius in seducing readers into accepting a pedophile and child molester. De Sade’s writing is about as subtle as a guillotine. You’d probably hate his four libertines, and I assume (hope) you’d disapprove of much that goes on in the novel. De Sade aimed to take his readers on a brutal ride. He liked the violent abusers he imagined and admired their thirst for rape, murder, torture, pedophilia, and disemboweling. The experience of reading this book is not that much different from putting yourself through a session of forced orgasms. You’re in it for the pain, but if it goes on for too long, you become completely desensitized and by the time you reach the end, on page 373, you are numb, exhausted, and bored.De Sade’s novel also illustrates the diversity of human sexual desires. He serves readers, similar to the way various food plates are served during a banquet, 600 sexual possibilities. As Aggrawal observed, sexual arousal, like allergies, can occur from anything under the sun, including the sun (if you don’t believe me, just google actirasty). De Sade pointed out, rightly, that a catalog of desires separate from the body of a story is monotonous. He wanted to blend the thrill of porn with the much drier taxonomy of paraphilias. Although, I admire de Sade for his contribution to our knowledge of unusual sexual practices, he hasn’t really done what he’s promised. He did cover quite a bit of ground. Depending on what you’re like, you can find examples that will disturb, disgust, shock, bore, or warm you and your deviant heart. But the number 600 is misleading. There are only a few dozen passions that repeat themselves, growing more extreme as the plot advances. After finishing the book, I was left with the impression that, as far as the diversity of human desires goes, de Sade wrote mostly about variations of coprophilia (especially coprophagia) and pygophilia. review: Stanley Milgram’s Obedience to Authority is a social psychological account of how humans have a tendency to follow orders regardless of consequences. Stanley Milgram’s Obedience to Authority is a social psychological account of how humans have a tendency to follow orders regardless of consequences. In a series of experiments carried out at Yale University, Milgram has challenged common sense perceptions about free will and morality. He has shown that in certain experimental conditions study participants - the “teachers” - administered increasingly powerful and painful electric shocks on an innocent person - the “learner”. Although the “learner” was not harmed during the experiments - he was an actor, and did not actually receive any electric shocks - the book is a troubling account of how far regular people will proceed in a concrete and measurable situation in which they are ordered by an authority figure to inflict increasing pain on a protesting victim.Milgram’s motivation for setting up and carrying out these experiments was to understand the psychological factors that made the Holocaust possible. The inhumane policies that systematically murdered millions of people may have originated primarily in the mind of one person, but they could not have been implemented at such a massive scale unless a large number of people obeyed orders. Ok, they may have existed a little bit, but not in a way that anyone today would be nostalgic about. Coontz has looked at pretty much all available historical data about families and family values and based on mounting evidence she concluded that (spoiler alert): families of the past were not at all idyllic and families of the present are not, by comparison, more dysfunctional. In other words, the past wasn’t that good and the present isn’t that bad. When I say it, it does not sound terribly optimistic, but Coontz manages to keep things hopeful. She actually strikes me as a bit of an idealist. By the time I was half way through the book, I was thinking that any argument that uses the expression “family values” is moralizing rather than mobilizing, not to mention that it’s based on myths about what families were like throughout history. Coontz, however, adopts an optimistic middle ground, where she doesn’t completely abandon the value of family values but broadens it to include community values and meaningful social network values that go beyond the ideas many of us have about traditional family borders.Overall, this is a rich scholarly text that unravels mythical conceits about love, parenting, the gendered division of labour, attitudes about family privacy, family rights, sexual practices and relationship types. review: Johann Hari argues that depression and anxiety are often reactive responses to life experiences, rather than innate brain chemical imbalances. The booJohann Hari argues that depression and anxiety are often reactive responses to life experiences, rather than innate brain chemical imbalances. The book is part memoir as Hari chronicles his battle with depression since early adolescence. For most of his teenage years and early adulthood he took antidepressants, which generally had a modest effect on improving his life. As an adult, with a background in journalism and social science, Hari began to rigurously investigate the flaws of his treatment, traveling the world to talk with an impressive number of scientists, psychologists, and people suffering from depression and anxiety and ing the scientific literature on the causes and treatment of depression. A large part of the book deals with reactive depression, which according to scientific consensus, is caused by the cumulative effects of things such as: childhood trauma, loneliness, lost connections to community, meaningful friends, and family; the loss of a sense of hope for the future; loss of love or a painful breakup; and a general lack of fulfillment. The more negative and painful experiences someone has had, the more likely it will be for them to feel depressed and anxious. Although, to his credit, Hari does not advocate for a complete halt of prescribing antidepressants, he is critical of the research practices of the pharmaceutical industry, which routinely push for chemical treatments for both endogenous and reactive forms of depression. Moreover, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, on average, are not very effective, and more research is needed if people are to receive better treatment. The book uses an evidence-based investigative approach. Hari is meticulous in his methods and the book is less self-help and more medical literature. However, the language is accessible and the stories of the people Hari traveled across the globe to interview are fascinating, insightful and moving. Broadly, the conclusion of the book is that people need to find ways to reconnect to others and form meaningful and compassionate connections with friends, lovers, family and community - a conclusion I firmly stand behind....more

He was also one of the expert witnesses in the trial of a US serviceman who took part in the abuse of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib in 2003. The gist of The Lucifer Effect–which offers a detailed analysis of SPE and the Abu Ghraib abuses-is that good people can become evil when placed in stressful or unusual circumstances. So, clearly, good and evil are interchangeable. Given the right setting (or wrong-depending on how you look at it), anyone can act cruelly. Instead of talking about “bad apples” we should be talking about the “bad barrel”. Cool, right? I thought so, too. In fact, Zimbardo used to be one of my favourite social psychologists. I read all of his publications, watched his TED talks, and read his blog entries with the ardour of the uninitiated. And then, my grad school methodology professor knocked the stuffing right out of me. Turns out that the seminal SPE (have you seen the movie?) was not peer-ed, it has biased and incomplete data, and its methods, procedures and validity are not great. The problem is that Zimbardo’s study presents humans as naturally conforming to an oppressive authority. When you look at his data, what it shows is that the students participating in his study were really eager to please him. There is no evidence in SPE for the hidden darkness of the human soul, or its submissiveness. In his vision, the very notion of physical space has been transformed in a future governed by advanced technology. From the first page, the reader is thrown into this alternative universe and - in order to start making sense of the fast pacing plot - needs to figure out how the physical world is organized and how far the reaching capabilities of technology go. As a result, for people who are unfamiliar with Gibson’s writing style, the book can seem somewhat confusing and disorienting at first. The plot is simple and pretty typical: a computer hacker is rescued from death by an underground organization, who in return ask him to hack into the system of another organization. review: This is a memoir about reading as an act of transgression. Classical Persian literature along with forbidden works of Western Literature - Nabokov, AuThis is a memoir about reading as an act of transgression. Classical Persian literature along with forbidden works of Western Literature - Nabokov, Austen, Fitzgerald, James and others - were read, discussed and critiqued by seven students of literature living in Tehran during the 1990s. They were all women. Every Thursday morning they re-created a sanctuary, a self-contained universe squeezed into one room in their teacher’s house. That was a place where they were free to keep or shed their mandatory black robes and head scarves. Imagine the pause before each young woman enters the room. Then picture the closing of the door that functioned to momentarily block out the tyranny of time and politics. Most of the women took off their robes and scarfs, shook their heads from side to side and burst into colour. A few kept their head coverings. But that was not the point. The important thing was the freedom to become distinct through personal choice, whether that was colour, hair length, fashion style or modest coverings. Each woman gained an inimitable shape, a unique expression of individuality. The work of literature that most resonated with their lives under an Islamic religious fundamentalist hold was Lolita. Despite Humbert’s attempts to erase the real Lolita, and replace her with his own perverted image of her, we can still glimpse her voice and her story if we pay close attention. She was a girl who used to enjoy ordinary instances of life – which really are extraordinary when you think about it – listening to music, reading, sunbathing, dancing and falling in love. Then, she was robbed of her childhood. Her past, her voice, and even her name, were taken away from her. The women secretly reading Lolita in Tehran understood all too well what it feels like to have regular life confiscated and driven underground. And their teacher, Azar Nafisi, wants readers to really see the women behind the veils: they never became what the cultural purists of their day tried to will them into becoming. ...more

The narrator, who hides behind the pseudonym Humbert, is a pedophile and a sexual predator. But he doesn’t see himself in this light - and he gets to write the story. In his mind he is a tragic lover seduced by young Lolita. He uses all of his wit and charm to seduce his readers into accepting his version of events. A quick glance at some of the s on goodreads shows that he did manage to deceive quite a few readers. A careful reading, though, exposes the cracks in Humbert’s narrative about how Lolita cunningly manipulated him into having sex with her and how she coldheartedly used him for his money.There are many examples of conflict between Humbert’s general presentation of events and details that slip through which put his sincerity and innocence under suspicion. For example, Lolita had a habit of crying after having sex with him, something that he coldheartedly dismisses as “salutary storm of sobs”. At one point Humbert complains that he has a “sensational but incomplete and unorthodox memory”, so clearly his words should be taken with a grain of salt. But, at another point, he boasts that he is “a very conscientious recorder” of past events. In high pressure situations, he shows how adept he is at jovially twisting the truth. He often complains about his mental health in ways that are meant to draw the reader’s sympathy. He implies that he is a victim of his obsession with young girls, and that Lolita takes advantage of all his vulnerabilities.Humbert is a bit too confident in his ability to distract readers from the fact that he is a murderer, a rapist and a child molester by his mastery of language. Early into the book he announces: “You can always count on a murderer for a fancy prose style.” Indeed, the language does not disappoint. The puns, the word games, the literary allusions, the linguistic tricks are all glorious. I think that Nabokov wanted to show how easy it is to sympathize with an abuser. That’s exactly the narrative Sade dismantles in Justine or The Misfortunes of Virtue and he does it - well, he does it sadistically.Sade transforms his readers into spectators of violence against virtuous young Justine. He is serving an alternative discourse about the merits of virtue. In his world we see a nightmarish spectacle of escalating abuse. No matter how hard Justine tries to derive a higher meaning from suffering, the textual audience of her victimization is only further stimulated by her tears and up their violence.Justine’s suffering is pointless, but Sade’s allegory makes a few interesting points. Between scenes of torture, Sade makes room for his philosophy. He thinks a novelist must describe man not only as he is, or wants to be, but also as what he is capable of being when subjected to the full impact of his vices. Sade wants to test common ideas about morality. He also wants to make his reader squirm.Sade portrays vice in the colors of hell, because he believes that anything less isn’t pure or honest. He wants to expose the sentimental narrative of his time as false. Around him, the political climate was a mess and ideas about divine justice weren’t making much sense. Sade puts Justine - who btw would have fit very nicely in a sentimental novel - inside a perverted narrative. She tells everyone she meets the tale of her suffering hoping to find mercy. Because Sade is author, she only meets perverts and her story only lubricates their imagination. She is virtuous and, as a consequence, she doesn’t adapt, doesn’t learn from past experiences, repeats the same pattern and is subjected to increasingly violent abuses. She refuses to face the facts of Sade’s world: virtue is punished and vice is rewarded.Sade violent demonstration re-enacts hierarchies of power. Everyone has to choose between two options: sinful agency or passive victimhood. Justine chooses the later. The arguments in the book reflect multiple problematic social and sexual attitudes. They also open up questions about whether there should be limits to what is expressed and if engaging with sadistic texts is ever a good idea. It’s about ordinary people trAnthony Marra’s A constellation of Vital Phenomena is not entirely credible, but nonetheless it is a strong debut novel. It’s about ordinary people trying to survive while living in a state of constant trauma caused by the Chechen wars. The raw recounting of the destructive conflicts between post-Soviet Russia, Chechen guerrillas and the jihadis are contrasted with profoundly compassionate insights about how people’s memories of events become ways of coping with historical abuses. The plot moves back and forth into the pasts and futures of characters. When their lives intersect, the intensity of their ancestors’ hatred tests the moral strength of the descendants. The way the characters are constructed feels a bit stretched, as if Marra created archetypes. This works on some level because each character’s arc will pleasantly tickle your brain. What’s missing, though, are those complex humans who you feel that you can connect with emotionally, not just cognitively. But, Marra is a brilliant story teller and the prose is beautiful. There are many graphic descriptions of torture that show the human capability for causing atrocities, and a thin undercurrent of hope for the resilience of the survivors. In the worst moments of war, Sonja - a doctor working in a run down, almost completely equipment-free hospital - compares life to a moth that pointlessly circles a dead bulb.
